results.title: Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg
results.creator_credit: Virginia Lumsden, Peter Butler and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House, October 14, 1988 and performed by the Australian Opera Chorus and the Elizabethan Philharmonic Orchestra, this opera is the only comedy that Richard Wagner ever wrote. Set in Nuremberg in the middle of the sixteenth century, it is a parable of art told in terms of a simple human love story. Within the context of middle-class town life, the opera symbolises the eternal conflict between the need for change, with Walther at its forefront, and the conservative forces of a too strongly held critical tradition, personified in Beckmesser. Sung in German with English subtitles, the conductor is Charles MacKerras and the director is Michael Hampe.

results.title: Die hard (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John McTiernan, Joel Silver, Lawrence Gordon, Silver Pictures, Gordon Co and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Directed by John McTiernan (Rollerball, The Thomas Crown affair, Last action hero), “Die hard” was the film that catapulted Bruce Willis from TV fame to movie stardom. Willis stars as John McClane, a New York policeman on Christmas vacation in Los Angeles, the city where his estranged wife and children have re-located. Attending his wife’s Christmas party, McClane is laying low in the bathroom when terrorists invade the building. Taking the entire staff hostage, the terrorists, lead by Hans Gruber (Alan Rickman), are depicted as intelligent, ruthless bloodletters who will stop at nothing to get millions of dollars out of the corporation. McClane is in his element (as is Willis), fighting the baddies single-handedly with one gun, some cunning plans and a dose of wry humour. “Die hard” features monstrous special effects, with exploding buildings, cars, helicopters and elevator shafts. McClane is a tough customer who terrorises the terrorists with his cheeky approach and inventive schemes. A classic David versus Goliath tale, this special edition of “Die hard” features three different theatrical trailers and an ad campaign featurette.

results.title: Die hard (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John McTiernan, Joel Silver, Lawrence Gordon, Silver Pictures, Gordon Co and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Bruce Willis stars as New York Detective, John McClane, newly arrived in Los Angeles to spend the Christmas holiday with his estranged wife (Bonnie Bedelia). But as McClane waits for his wife’s office party to break up, terrorists seize control of the building. While terrorists leader Hans Gruber and his savage henchmen round up hostages, McClane slips away unnoticed. Armed with only a service revolver and his own cunning, McClane launches his own one-man war. A crackling action thriller from beginning to end, “Die Hard” explodes with heart-stopping suspense. Also stars Alan Rickman, Alexander Godunov and Bonnie Bedelia. From the novel by Roderick Thorp.

results.title: Die Hard
results.creator_credit: Jeb Stuart, Steven E. de Souza, Lawrence Gordon, Joel Silver, John McTiernan, Matthew Yuricich, Marilyn Vance, Jackson De Govia, Beau Marks, 20th Century Fox, Silver Pictures and Gordon Company
results.brief_description: NYPD cop John McClane’s plan to reconcile with his estranged wife is thrown for a serious loop when, minutes after he arrives at her office, the entire building is overtaken by a group of terrorists. With little help from the LAPD, wisecracking McClane sets out to single-handedly rescue the hostages and bring the bad guys down.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.title: Die Fledermaus
results.creator_credit: Hugh Davison, Anthony Besch, Brian Adams, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Opera Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on July 10th 1982 for television, this famous operetta by Johann Strauss, libretto by Richard Genee and Carl Haffner, has once again proven to be a favourite with the audience. Witty, charming, comical, “Die Fledermaus” is a tale of a philandering husband, a masked ball, a wife disguised in order to trick her philandering husband, of revenge, and of other dubious and mischievous schemes which eventually result in total confusion for one and all - one may ask could it possibly have anything to do with the champagne! The great Joan Sutherland (Rosalinde), along with Robert Gard (Gabriel von Eisenstein) lead a superb cast including Anson Austin (Alfred), Monique Brynnel (Adele), Gordon Wilcock (Blind), Michael Lewis (Dr Falke), Gregory Yurisich (Frank), Graeme Ewer (Frosch), Anne Maree McDonald (Ida), Pieter Van Der Stolk (Ivan) and Heather Begg (Prince Orlofsky). Also features the Australian Opera Chorus with Martin Handley as chorus master, the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra with Ladislav Jasek as concert master and Richard Bonynge, conductor, and a cameo appearance by Kelvin Coe and Lois Strike from the Sydney Dance Company. The stage-set and design is eloquent in its simplicity, as too the costumes and make-up. An excellent production. Sung and spoken in English.

results.title: Die Fledermaus
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Burton, Richard Gregson, Leopold Lindtberg, Royal Opera House Covent Garden, BBC-TV and Arts Intl
results.brief_description: The Royal Opera Chorus and the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, conducted by Placido Domingo, appear in this traditional Viennese comedy - the best known and most loved operetta by the King of the waltz, Johann Strauss the younger. Sung in German, with libretto in German and English, but no subtitles. This version has Kiri Te Kanawa as Rosalinde, Hermann Prey as Eisenstein, Hildegard Heichele as Adele and Benjamin Luxon as Falke. Music is directed by Sir Colin Davis.

results.title: Die Flambierte frau = A Woman in flames
results.brief_description:
A raw analysis of class, gender and sex, ‘Women in Flames’ centres on Eva, who one day, without warning, walks out of her stultifying middle-class marriage and into the world of high-class prostitution. Soon she begins an intense relationship with Chris, a fellow prostitute. They move in together but tensions emerge as Eva embraces her sexual freedom and sheds her middle-class moral scruples and Chris’s possessive instincts surface. Set almost entirely in fashionable interiors, stylishly photographed, and with music by Peer Raben the film begs comparison with Fassbinder’s work. Yet Van Ackeren’s film lacks Fassbinder’s assured hand. Cool and distanced, his study of a middle and upper class world ruled by money, power, and sex - where the unexpected and bizarre lie just beneath the tranquil surface, hovers uncertainly between voyeurism and social criticism.

Credits: Director, Robert van Ackeren ; writers, Robert van Ackeren, Catherina Zwerenz ; photography, Jurgen Jurges ; editing, Tanja Schmidbauer ; music, Peer Raben.
Cast: Gudrun Landgrebe, Mathieu Carriere, Hanns Zischler, Gabriele Lafari, Matthias Fuchs.

results.title: Die Deutschen luftwaffe. No. 6. Bombers & bomber ops 1942-1945
results.creator_credit: Mickey Shephard, Mike Croker and VAF Productions
results.brief_description: This documentary video contains some rare archival footage of the German Luftwaffe carrying out some of their bombing operations during the years 1942-1945 of World War II including photo-intelligence surveillance, aerial bombings, strikes on allied convoys with anti-ship missiles and night bomber raids against the British. At one stage during 1942, the Luftwaffe were capable of launching up to 1000 sorties per day. However by 1944 due to the growing effectiveness of Allied air power, the Luftwaffe bombing force began to decline, until Germany’s eventual surrender in May 1945. Aeroplane enthusiasts, and particularly those into war planes, will enjoy this documentary for its informative and historical visuals and its coverage of the various bombers used by the Luftwaffe, including the Junkers Ju-88 and Ju-188, the Dornier 217 series and the Heinkel He-111 and He-177, as well as flying boats and float planes operating from the Mediterranean through to the Arctic Ocean (in rare colour footage). Narrated by Brian Matthews.

results.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.brief_description: While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed precedes the Disney film by over a decade.

constellations_primary.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_primary.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Storytelling through shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play has brought stories to life for thousands of years and is still used today.

results.title_for_label: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.description:
You may not have heard of German animator Lotte Reiniger. She turned her home into a DIY animation studio and pioneered animating silhouettes by shooting homemade puppets frame-by-frame against sheets of lead.

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.
description_for_label:

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.

images.credit_line: A still from Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed). Courtesy Alamy.
images.alt_text: A yellow image with black silhouettes of fantastical creatures and princes demonstrating the early animation style of lotte reiniger
